Context: 2.1.1 Summary Description of the Project (G1.2)
The Chinko conservation area REDD+ project is an initiative initiated by African Parks to sustainably
manage a part of eastern Central African Republic (CAR), a unique area where savannah and tropical
forest meet. The project is intended as a grouped one, in which the long-term vision is to manage multiple
sectors of eastern CAR in the prefectures of Mbomou, Haute-Kotto and Haut-Mbomou (See in Figure 1 the
geographical boundaries). African Parks has an agreement with the CAR government in place since 2014
for the protection of four hunting zones and signed a new one in 2020 for the inclusion of new ones.
The conditions prior to the implementation of the project had several factors that impacted the well-being
of communities and community groups living on the periphery of the project area. These include insecurity
in the region, persistent conflict between transhumant pastoralists and local communities, lack of education
and employment opportunities, and poor healthcare. These factors had an impact on the ecosystems and
biodiversity of the region as well, where practices like unsustainable hunting and an economy of illegal
wildlife trade, transhumant pastoralism and unsustainable agricultural activities were performed widely.
The overall objective of the project is to secure a core protected area in eastern CAR and to actively engage
in the land use planning and sustainable management of the surrounding areas in order to restore and
improve ecosystem functions and habitat, through community engagement, law enforcement and
restoration and conservation activities. Below are the specific objectives.
Climate objectives: Enhance the restoration of natural ecosystems, leading to increasing the CO storage 2
and avoiding the emissions resulting from disturbance and conversion.
Community objectives: Improve the lives, livelihoods and safety of local communities by implementing
community projects, land use planning and sustainable resources management.
Biodiversity objectives: Enhance the conditions for conservation and habitat management including
restoration and maintenance of biodiversity and associated ecosystem services while improving the
population of endangered species.
The measures to be implemented by the project are focused on reducing the impact of the main agents
and drivers of deforestation and conversion, by creating new and more sustainable opportunities for those
agents in the wider landscape. These activities include sensitisation of the local communities and
transhumance pastoralists, the establishment of pastoralism corridors and more sustainable natural
resource use. Moreover, the project will increase employment opportunities, continuation of biodiversity
monitoring and restoration of natural areas among others. The success in the implementation of these
activities is expected to generate greenhouse gases (GHG) emissions reductions (Check section 2.1.11 for
more details of the project activities).
Upon the implementation of the project activities described above, the project is expected to generate an
estimated annual average of net emissions reduction of 442,839 tCO2e and a total of 4,558,205 tCO2e for
Sep 2016 – Dec 2026 period, according to the Non-Permanence Risk assessment the buffer discount
obtained was 6.5% but the minimum assumed is 10%, therefore, after applying the buffer the average
amount of tradable VCUs per year during this period is 398,553 and totalling 4,102,366 for Sep 2016 – Dec
2026 period.

Contribution of project to Social well-being:
• The project activity quite clearly leads to the
alleviation of poverty in the long term by generating
direct as well as indirect job opportunities to the local
population for various activities involved in
transportation, loading, unloading and stacking of
biomass in the plant etc. This will also improve the
income generation of the persons involved with biomass
11

VCS Project Description
collection, transportation and handling, resulting into
betterment of their livelihoods. Therefore the project
activity is a step towards social development.
Contribution of project to Economic well-being
• The project has also provided economic value to
agricultural and wood wastes. The project has created
business opportunities for local stakeholders such as
suppliers, contractors etc.
• The main resources for thermal energy generation are
biomass fuels such as rice husk, wood waste, etc. are
collected from the farmers out of their field and brought
to the project, thus generate additional revenue on
account of supply of these crop residues to the project,
which are otherwise being under-utilized. In other words,
the plant is generating commercial value to crop residues
enabling the farmers to get better price out of their
produce augmenting their income. The above benefits due
to project activity ensure that the project contributes
to the social and economic well being in the region.
Contribution of project to Environmental well-being
• Mitigating emission of GHG (CO ), as the biomass used is 2
carbon neutral;
• The project will use biomass that is available in the
region and which otherwise gets accumulated, leading to
possible environmental hazards.
Contribution of project to Technological well-being
• Adopting an advanced and sustainable technology for long-
term benefits.
This project will generate thermal energy to cater its in-
house requirement (thereby replacing the coal based heat
generation) is in itself clean project as they replace the
fossil fuel based energy by renewable biomass fuel based
energy. Since, this project uses biomass, which, in
itself, is considered to be carbon neutral, the GHG
emission is taken as zero and its use is in line with
state government's priorities. However, there is no law
enforcing the use of these biomass fuels.

{'project_name': 'Longido and Monduli Rangelands Carbon Project', 'project_summary': 'This project features implementation of rapid rotational grazing practices by dense aggregations of livestock to restore perennial grasses on degraded rangelands across 970,685 hectares in northern Tanzania. These new grazing practices are additional because they differ from the currently practiced seasonal shifts in grazing activity from wet to dry season ranges, and the new practices would not be possible without carbon revenues to support governance and monitoring of grazing activities. Rapid rotational grazing will enhance adaptation to climate change by improving soil water holding capacity, increasing surface water availability and providing grass banks as a hedge against drought. Habitat improvement from new grazing practices will result in biodiversity benefits in the form of improved habitat inside wildlife corridors between iconic High Conservation Areas such as Serengeti, Kilimanjaro, Nairobi, and Tsavo National Parks and their associated ecosystems and enhance diversity of endemic taxa of plants, birds and insects. Finally, the project will provide direct benefits to dozens of pastoralist communities in form of funds for bursaries to support women and the poorest community members as well as to construct water capture structures and infrastructure for delivering livestock to market. The project is expected to remove more than 62 million tons CO2e over the project lifetime of 40 years, or more than 1.5 million tons CO2e a year on average.', 'project_state_province': 'Arusha Region', 'project_country': 'Tanzania', 'project_latitude': -2.79, 'project_longitude': 36.43}

{'project_name': 'Tianpeng Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation', 'project_summary': 'The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Southern Pengzhou City within Chengdu City, Sichuan Province
of China, with a total acreage of 12,437 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the
implementation of this project, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the
scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario.
Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of
methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is
more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emission reduction
than the continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which results
in not only large amount of methane (CH4) emissions but also low rice productivity by
replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which shortens
the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. Hence, with the proposed
project activity, an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 4.55 tCO2e/ha for singlecropping
rice is expected. Annual average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the
project activity is 56,539 tCO2e/year, and the total GHG emission reductions are 565,390
tCO2e during the fixed 10 years crediting period.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
- Increase the number of local individuals who have relevant skills due to diversified
educational opportunities from trainings;
- Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.', 'project_state_province': 'Sichuan Province', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 30.92, 'project_longitude': 103.19}

{'project_name': 'THE NAGALAND 4 CHANGE REDD+ PROJECT', 'project_summary': 'The Nagaland 4 Change is proposing an AFOLU Project under REDD+ Category in Peren district of Nagaland, North-eastern India. Nagaland is one of the few states of India having forest cover more than 50% of its geographical area. The forests provide multiple goods and services to the local Naga communities, such as fruits, seeds, medicines and recreation. Moreover, Nagaland state is located in the Indo-Burma Biodiversity Hotspot Region, which is among the 36 most biodiverse regions of the Earth. Some of the rare and endangered species, such as Spotted Linsang (Prionodon pardicolor), Clouded Leopard (Neofelis nebulosa), and Black Softshell Turtle (Nilssonia nigricans). In addition, forests of Nagaland protect the fragile hilly ecosystems of the state by preventing soil erosion and landslides.
   
However, specifically forests in Peren are gradually reducing in size. As well as the forests are also becoming increasingly prone to the fires during the dry summer months (April, May and June). Because of high anthropogenic pressures, the forests are also under extreme stress as a result of firewood collections. Therefore, Nagaland 4 Change, the Project Proponent is proposing a forest conservation project through funding from carbon financing under Verra VCS Mechanism. The main aim of the projects are as follows:
1.	Conservation of existing forests by protecting the forest cover.
2.	Increasing the forest cover as well as increasing density of the vegetation in forests.
3.	Enhancing the capacity of carbon storage of the forests, therefore generating carbon credits revenue out of it.
4.	Monitoring and reporting of the rare and endangered flora and fauna living the forests.
5.	Providing livelihood improvement to the local Naga communities through various interventions such as improved cookstoves, clean drinking water, etc.', 'project_state_province': 'Nagaland', 'project_country': 'India', 'project_latitude': 25.51, 'project_longitude': 93.74}

Context: JOINT PROJECT DESCRIPTION & MONITORING REPORT: VCS Version 3
Apart from generation of renewable electricity, the grouped project activity and project activity
instances proposed to be included under it would contribute to the sustainable development of the
region - socially, environmentally and economically. Ministry of Environment and Forests (MoEF),
Government of India, has stipulated the following indicators for sustainable development.
1. Social well-being;
2. Economic well-being;
3. Environmental well-being; and
4. Technological well-being
Social well-being
 The project activity instances under grouped project activity will result in creating job
opportunities for the local population on temporary and permanent basis. Manpower is required
both during erection and operation of the renewable energy projects. This would result in the
improvement in living standards of the local community.
 The installation of the renewable energy projects also led to development of basic infrastructure
like roads, communication with the nearby cities etc. which also improved in living standards
of the local population.
Economic well-being
 The project activity instances under grouped project activity will create direct and indirect job
opportunities to the local community during installation and operation of the renewable energy
projects.
 The investment for the project activity instances under grouped project activity would lead to
the improvement in the economic activity in the local area.
Environmental well-being
 The project activity instances under grouped project activity utilizes renewable energy for
generating electricity which otherwise would have been generated through alternate fuel (most
likely - fossil fuel) based power plants, contributing to reduction in specific emissions (emissions
of pollutant/unit of energy generated) including GHG emissions. As renewable energy projects
produce no end products in the form of solid waste (ash etc.), they address the problem of solid
waste disposal encountered by most other sources of power. Being a renewable resource, to
generate electricity contributes to resource conservation. Thus the project causes no negative
impact on the surrounding environment.
Technological well-being:
Clean technology transfer in renewable energy generation and optimal use of renewable energy
in the industry.
There is no any provision is required to monitor and report these sustainable development
indicators as per national rules and regulations.

Question: What is the methodology of this project?

Context: 3.2 Applicability of Methodology
As established in the methodology, it is applicable under the following conditions:
• The land subject to the project activity does not fall in wetland category
The A/R CDM project activity is not implemented on wetlands. There are no wetlands in the project area.
Uruguay Land categories can be checked in the following web site from the Environmental Government
Entity https://www.ambiente.gub.uy/visualizador/index.php?vis=sig
• Soil disturbance attributable to the project activity does not cover more than 10 per cent of area
in each of the following types of land, when these lands are included within the project boundary:
(i) Land containing organic soils;
36

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
(ii) Land which, in the baseline, is subjected to land use and management practices and receives inputs
listed in appendices 1 (Cropland in which soil disturbance is restricted) and 2 (Grassland in which soil
disturbance is restricted) to this methodology.
Soil Disturbance
The disturbance to the soil attributable to the project activity covers plough strips of 0,8 m width every 4
m to the effectively planted area, representing 11,7 % of the total ‘Bugnavilla’ project area and 20% of
the ‘Bugnavilla’ VCS project boundary area. Having said this, the soil types of the project cannot be
categorized as (i) organic or (ii) grassland in which soil disturbance is restricted. According to 2006 IPCC
Guidelines (Annex 3A.5, Chapter 3, Volume 4), organic soils must have at least 12 percent organic carbon
by weight (i.e., about 20 percent organic matter). As it is described by Silva Silva30 organic matter content
in brunosoles soils (from Coneat 2) range from 3.1 to 8.2%. In this soil type the organic matter content,
and hence the organic carbon, does not reach the 20% of the organic soils. Given that, as above stated
‘Bugnavilla’ project soils are classified as Coneat 2, it is concluded that the soil types of the project are
not organic.
‘Bugnavilla’ project lands are characterized by grazing activity with regular usage capacity and without
technological improvements, implanted pastures or crops. These natural grasslands do not receive
intensive management with added agricultural inputs such as fertilization, reseeding, etc. The soils are
of reduced natural fertility and current erosion is relatively low. Hence, the Project is applicable to this
methodology.
A project activity applying this methodology shall also comply with the applicability conditions of the tools
contained within the methodology and applied by the project activity.
This standard establishes a set of specific requirements for afforestation and reforestation project
activities, among which stands out the eligibility of the land.
In order to demonstrate the land eligibility, the PP should follow the “Procedures to Demonstrate the
Eligibility of Lands for Afforestation and Reforestation CDM Project Activities” in which Project participants
shall provide evidence that the land within the planned project boundary does not contain forest and that
the activity is a reforestation or afforestation project activity The land eligibility is demonstrated though
the use of satellite imagery showing that vegetation on the land has been below the forest threshold
according to the definition of forest adopted by Uruguay. In this regard, the table below provides the
details of the adopted definition
37

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
The satellite images displayed below show that the land did not contain forest on 31 December 1985 nor
in 2009, 2013 and 2016. Satellite image from July 2021, shows the forest plantation at ‘Bugnavilla’ site.
The land was covered by natural pastures and some scattered trees planted for cattle shade not
qualifying as forest.
38

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
According to the baseline scenario the project pervious land use was grassland (management practices
listed in appendix 2 apply). The project will be implemented on degraded lands which are expected to
remain in a degraded state in the absence of the project. Extensive grazing activity have made the soil
lost the original vegetation and a fraction of the soil organic matter, an essential component determining
land productivity, leading to constraints to productivity.
The change in vegetation due to grazing reduced the turnover of plant residues and, consequently the
organic matter content of the soil, thus leading to a more degraded state of soils.
The project will be implemented on degraded lands which are expected to remain in a degraded state in
the absence of the project. Evidence is provided here showing that, due to extensive grazing activity
practiced for more than 300 years, with frequent periods of overgrazing, lands have lost the original
vegetation and a fraction of the soil organic matter, an essential component determining land
productivity, leading to constraints to productivity, particularly in those areas affected by severe erosion.
In addition, due to frequent periods of overgrazing causing the soil to become exposed to erosive
processes (i.e., due to lack of vegetation cover) combined with dominating moderate slopes in the terrain,
gully erosion processes have affected most of the lands within project boundaries.
Native vegetation in the project region was originally composed mainly by tall grasses and shrubs. The
turnover of plant residues maintained relatively high levels of organic matter in the soil. Introduction of
39

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
cattle in the 17th century brought about a degradation of the vegetation, which became dominated by
grasses that were kept short by grazing, particularly after introduction of sheep a few decades later. The
sheep and cattle extensive grazing activity has prevailed, more or less unchanged, until present. Due to
the extensive nature, the production system is vulnerable to climate extremes, the relatively frequent
droughts that occur in Uruguay (e.g., dry periods every summer, with extreme droughts every 10 years or
so) are associated to overgrazing.
Grazing practices applied on all the lands included within project boundaries during long periods of time
have resulted in significant losses of carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus and other nutrients from the soil, and
have also resulted in significant alterations to the vegetation cover and the biological diversity.
The change in vegetation due to grazing reduced the turnover of plant residues and, consequently the
organic matter content of the soil, thus leading to a more degraded state of soils. Some recent studies
support this statement. Piñeiro et al (2006)1 (peer-review study) have found that 370 years of grazing
have caused, on average for 11 grassland sites in Argentina and Uruguay, decreases in soil organic
nitrogen content (−880 kg ha−1 or −19%), soil organic carbon content (−21,200 kg ha−1 or −22%) and
net primary productivity (−2,192 kg ha−1 or −24%). The conditions in which this study was conducted
match those of all the sites included in the project activity.
Another peer-review study prepared by Altesor et al. (1998)27 arrived to similar conclusions. Five sample
plots on grassland sites in North Uruguay were measured in 1935 and revisited in 1990. It was concluded
that continued grazing causes an increase in the number of weedy species and decreasing the palatable
forage species. This is an indicator of a presently and continuous degrading process. The findings of this
study are applicable to all sites included in the project activity.
The First Report of Uruguay to the UN Convention to Combat Desertification prepared by DINACEA
(National Environmental Directorate) in 20003 governmental peer-review study) states in its Section 2.1
that the way in which extensive grazing is practiced deteriorates the natural pasture since it is based on
the assumption that the natural grassland ecosystem can support mismatches between grazing pressure
and forage availability induced by weather and/or market. The report also states that the strong
fluctuations in the prices of major agricultural products hinder an adequate planning of the production
units, which is essential for the conservation of natural resources. In Section 1.6 of that report, it is stated
that the climatic variations frequently produce “forage crises” both in summer and winter times, resulting
in overgrazing and a consequent loss of species. The concepts included in this report are valid for all
land units included within project boundaries, since previous land use in all sites has been extensive
livestock production based on grazing.
1 Piñeiro, G., Paruelo, J.M. and Oesterheld, M. 2006. Potential long-term impacts of livestock introduction on carbon and nitrogen
cycling in grasslands of Southern South America. Global Change Biology 12:1267–1284.
2 Altesor, A., Di Landro, E, May, H. and Ezcurra, E. 1998. Long-term species change in a Uruguayan grassland. Journal of Vegetation
Science, 9:173-180
3 First National Report (2000) submitted by DINACEA (acronym in Spanish of Uruguayan National Environment Direction) to UNCCD (United
Nations Convention to Combat Desertification)

Context: 2.1.1 Summary Description of the Project (G1.2)
Liangdu Afforestation Project (hereafter refer to as “the project”) is located in Liupanshui City, Guizhou
Province of China,Guizhou is an inland province, bordering Yunnan to the west, Sichuan to the northwest,
Hunan to the east and Chongqing to the North. Guizhou province has a total population of 34 million. The
project aims to plant native species on barren lands for GHG removal whilst contributing to local
sustainable development goals. 23,720ha (355,800 Mu12) of the forest was planted on barren lands in
Shuicheng county, Pan county, Liuzhi special district which used to be poor sustainable ecological
environment and karst rocky desertification..
The project involves including 1 district and 2 counties: Shuicheng county, Pan county, Liuzhi special
district, The project zone with a total population of nearly 2,900,753. All the barren lands for afforestation
activities belong to the villagers and the village committees manage the lands on behalf of villagers.
Guizhou Xinzhanxin Agricultural Technology Co., Ltd. (hereafter referred to as Guizhou Xinzhanxin) has
been fully authorized by all the village committees to act as the project proponent to implement project
management and monitoring, and to sell VCUs generated from the project so that Guizhou Xinzhanxin
consolidate the offset resources into sizeable forestry offset projects. Guizhou Xinzhanxin will profit-share
with the villagers from selling VCUs. The implementation of the project activity has provided 15,220 jobs
for local villagers, among which 70 percent are women.
The project activity aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate change;
- Enhance biodiversity conservation by increasing the connectivity of forests;
- Improve soil and water conservation in the Karst region;
- Generate income and job opportunities for local communities.
There is no natural renewal and reforestation before the project, and all sites were covered by the barren
hill and degraded lands. The main objective species are China fir, Cypresses, Pinus yunnanensis and
Masson pine which are native species according to the baseline survey.
12A Chinese metric unit of area, 1ha = 15 Mu.

{'project_name': 'Shanxi Xiadian CMM Power Generation Project', 'project_summary': 'Shanxi Xiadian CMM Power Generation Project (hereinafter referred to as the Project) will utilize the low concentration coal mine methane (CMM) from Xiadian coal mine for power generation to supply electricity to the coal mine where the project is located. The central geographical coordinates are east longitude 112.911585° and north latitude 36.530075°. The Project Owner is Xiangyuan Luxin Coal Mine Methane Power Generation Co., Ltd. \r\nPrior to the implementation of the project, xiadian coal mine was equipped with CMM extraction facilities and all extracted CMM was vented into the atmosphere directly; the electricity consumed at coal mines was imported from NCPG; the heat was provided by waste coal boilers. For CMM treatment and heat supply, baseline scenario is the same as the scenario existing prior to the implementation of the project activity. For electricity supply, the NCPG provides the equivalent amount of electricity produced by the Project in the baseline. \r\nThe purpose of the Project is to utilize the extracted CMM with low concentration methane concentration to produce electricity. No coal bed methane (CBM) or ventilation air methane (VAM) utilization is involved. Fifteen sets of CMM power generators will be installed with a total installed capacity of 7.5MW (8*0.5 MW+7*0.5 MW), destroying 16.25 million m3 of methane annually. After the full operation of the Project, the expected annual exported electricity will be 31850 MWh, which will be supplied to the coal mine first through the electricity distribution network in Xiadian coal mine area, and then to NCPG if there is any electricity surplus, replacing the electricity that would otherwise have been purchased from the NCPG and displace part of the electricity generated by NCPG dominated by fossil fuel-fired power plants.', 'project_state_province': 'Shanxi', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 36.53, 'project_longitude': 112.91}

Context: 2.1.1 Summary Description of the Project (G1.2)
The Bajo Atrato REDD+ Project (BARP) is an initiative designed to promote climate change mitigation
and adaptation, maintain biodiversity, and create alternative livelihoods under the United Nations
Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD+) program. The Project Zone of
the initial instance is 313,082 hectares, located in the highly biodiverse region of the Biogeographic
Chocó (or Tumbes-Chocó-Magdalena) in the lower part of the Atrato River basin and its deltaic system in
the Gulf of Urabá (in the Caribbean Sea). The region is home to floodplains, hills, mountain ranges and
lush waterfalls; it has a direct connection with a complex of swamps and wetlands with very humid tropical
9 Managed for biodiversity conservation in this context means areas where specific management measures are being
implemented as a part of project activities with an objective of enhancing biodiversity conservation, e.g. enhancing
the status of endangered species
10 Per IUCN’s Red List of Threatened Species
11 In the absence of direct population or occupancy measures, measurement of reduced threats may be used as
evidence of benefit
CCB v3.0, VCS v3.3
14

CCB & VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION:
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
forests, which makes its ecological conditions unique compared to other Chocó forests (PNN, 2019). The
Project is part of one of the world’s 34 biodiversity hotspots and will contribute to conserving areas of
influence of Los Katios National Natural Park in Colombia and Darién National Park in Panama, both
critical conservation strategies to maintain biodiversity and ecological functions throughout the Darien
Gap area from the Caribbean coast to the Pacific coast along the Colombian-Panamanian border.
The BARP project zone is composed of 72 communities, gathered in collective territories of nine Afro-
Colombian Community Councils. The project will directly support the livelihoods of these 72 communities,
composed of approximately 10,291 families and a population of 33,040 people. Despite global and
regional importance, the area’s forests continue to suffer an uncontrolled conversion to agricultural land,
and a progressive degradation of the forest due to indiscriminate logging, the expansion of the agricultural
frontier, forest fires, extensive livestock, and illicit crops. The lack of employment opportunities,
infrastructure and basic services, and the promotion of illicit economies, lead the local population to clear
forests for income generation.
In response to the threats to the Choco Biogeographic landscape in the Bajo Atrato region, the nine (9)
Community Councils, their 72 communities, and Wildlife Works decided to create the BARP, which has
the following objectives:
▪ Climate: Mitigating climate change and its effects through the reduction of CO2 emissions produced by
deforestation and the development of adaptation strategies to climate variability.
▪ Community: Improve the quality of life of communities by strengthening self-government, governance,
and the development of sustainable production systems.
▪ Biodiversity: Contribute to the conservation of biodiversity through community-based forest
management, land appropriation, and forest monitoring, control, and surveillance.
The climate benefits of the Project are expected to include an average emission reduction of 485,291 t
CO2e per year, and a total of 15,044,035 t CO2e during the project lifetime. The project will generate
significant benefits for the community and biodiversity. In terms of community benefits, existing livelihoods
will be strengthened, and new sustainable livelihoods designed to reduce pressure on the environment
while increasing community well-being. Likewise, the project will direct efforts to strengthen food
sovereignty, improve critical infrastructures for local ethnodevelopment, increase the effective
participation of women, youth and the elderly, pursue local climate change adaptation strategies, and
promote the well-being of the community in general. Biodiversity benefits will be achieved through greater
protection of the forest and habitat, increased control and surveillance, recurrent monitoring, and the
enforcement of territorial boundaries. The project will protect the critical habitat of important populations of
ten threatened species according to the IUCN Red List, including the Baudó guan (Penelope ortoni), the
black-headed spider monkey (Ateles fusciceps), Baird’s tapir (Tapirus bairdii), the great green macaw
(Ara ambiguus), the cotton-top tamarin (Saguinus oedipus), and almanegra de Uraba (Magnolia
katiorum).

{'project_name': 'Bajo Atrato REDD+ Project', 'project_summary': 'The purpose of the REDD+ Bajo Atrato project is to reduce GHG emissions from deforestation and forest degradation activities, envisioning that the efforts of the communities inhabiting and owning the territories where it is located are materialized in actions that lead to forest conservation and the improvement of living conditions. The project is located in the northwest of Colombia, in the Department of Chocó, between the municipalities of Riosucio and Carmen del Darién, in the lower basin of the Atrato River, which is part of the Darién area. In the area of the project’s first instance, the following Afro-descendant communal lands are grouped: the Quiparadó River Basin Community Council, the Curbaradó River Community Council, the Salaquí River Basin Community Council, the Cacarica River Basin Community Council, the Truandó Medio La Teresita Community Council, the Bocas de Taparal Community Council, the Dos Bocas Chintado Community Council, the La Nueva Truandó Community Council, and the Clavellino Community Council.\r\nThe actions that will make possible to reduce deforestation and forest degradation in the project area are aligned with the needs and purposes  identified during the first meetings with the communities and while conducting the prior, free and informed consent process. These actions are aimed at achieving four major purposes: strengthening of governance and community management; improvement of community welfare; provision of social and community infrastructure; and boost of sustainable livelihoods and environmental protection, basic sanitation and aqueducts. The lands in the project area include tropical pluvial forests with transition to cold and very humid tropical forests. There, forests, grasslands, secondary vegetation, swampy areas and agroecosystems are found. In these areas, deforestation is associated with wood extraction, agricultural frontier expansion, illicit crop cultivation, and unplanned infrastructure construction.', 'project_state_province': 'Department of Chocó', 'project_country': 'Colombia', 'project_latitude': 7.35, 'project_longitude': 77.39}

The project is located in Narok County, Kenya (between latitudes 0°50’ and 1°50'S, and
longitudes 35°28’ and 36°25’E). The ecosystem is situated along the international border
between Kenya and Tanzania in equatorial East Africa (34.7° to 35.4° E, 1.2° to 1.7° S).
The project area encompasses the entire Greater Maasai Mara Ecosystem and surrounds,
extending eastwards to the county border to include the grasslands that are currently not under
conservancies (Figure 2). Currently there are 10 conservancies identified, with a further 7
identified to be incorporated in the first 5 years of the project. Please refer to e-Appendix 1 to

{'project_name': 'One Mara Carbon Project', 'project_summary': 'The One Mara Carbon Project (OMCP) is an ecosystem-level conservation initiative that aims to protect ecological resources and provide economic and social co-benefits for communities by incentivizing conservancy formation and grassland restoration in the Maasai Mara landscape in Kenya. The goal of OMCP is to restore the degraded rangelands through improved grazing management and prevent further loss of grasslands by providing alternative livelihoods for communities, build resilient conservancies, ensure biodiversity conservation, and enhance tourism. This region is world-renown for the expansive rangelands where agropastoralists and wildlife co-exist. However, historical land sub-division into small, fenced land parcels and long term extensive grazing by livestock has led to land degradation, including the gradual loss in soil organic carbon (SOC). Communities living within the ecosystem depend on the condition of the grasslands to provide livelihoods that will meet their socio-economic needs. Implementing climate change mitigation measures and halting land degradation are vital to ensuring the longevity of this world-famous conservation area.', 'project_state_province': 'Narok County', 'project_country': 'Kenya', 'project_latitude': -1.3, 'project_longitude': 35.22}

demonstrably reduce net GHG emissions of cropland systems by increasing soil carbon
stocks, reducing soil N2O emissions, and/or reducing CH4 emissions.

Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.0 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
GHG removals generated by this project will not be used for compliance with binding limits to
GHG emissions since such limits are not enforced in Paraguay. There are no emissions trading
programs in place in the country.
Other Forms of Environmental Credit
1.16.1
The grouped project is not being used to create other environmental credits.
1.17 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Leakage Management
1.16.2
The Forestal Apepu Carbon Project aims to increase the carbon stock of former agricultural land
and implanted pastures through afforestation. Leakage would only occur if pre-project activities
by previous owners would be shifted somewhere else in detriment of natural forests and/or
ecosystems. The risk of leakage is low. As a known fact, to date, previous owners have not shifted
pre-project activities to any other region were deforestation/forest conversion is allowed.
Commercially Sensitive Information
None.
Sustainable Development
The project contributes to the national forest sector by providing proof of concept and
implementation of models aligned to political goals, such as the national plan of reforestation
(Decree Nº 10,147 of 2012), governmental efforts to formalize the biomass sector (Decree Nº
4056/2015), and the contribution to the National Determined Contributions of the country,
where afforestation is highlighted as a prominent measure.
On the other hand, the Apepu Carbon Project will be one of the first to introduce the carbon
component, which will bring about proof of concept and more experience in the region. The
project managers will inform the national authorities of the Project, to avoid any possible double
accounting in the future, and contribute to any governmental efforts in this regard.
Further Information
Additional information is provided in the Appendix and in the relevant sections.

“Avoided Unplanned Deforestation & Degradation” (AUDD) project category. The project will not pursue IFM nor
ANR activities in any of the project areas. Some of the project activities do occur on wetlands; however the specific
carbon pools and GHG sources have not been accounted for as their exclusion leads to conservative estimates of
the total GHG emission reductions. The methodology VM0006 establishes that both below ground biomass and
soil organic carbon are optional carbon pools and may be conservatively excluded.

B.2. Justification of the choice of the methodology and why it is applicable to the project
activity:
The application of the baseline methodology AM0029 to the proposed project is justified for satisfying
the three conditions:
(cid:151) Condition 1: The project activity is the construction and operation of a new nature gas fired grid-
connected electricity generation plant.
The project activity is a new nature gas fired grid-connected electricity generation plant and no other
fuel except natural gas is consumed. The project activity is currently under construction and will be
commission completely in August of 2007.
(cid:151) Condition 2: The geographical/physical boundaries of the baseline grid can be clearly identified and
information pertaining to the grid and estimated baseline emissions is publicly available.
The electricity generated by the proposed project will be sold to Zhejiang Power Grid, which is an
integrated part of the East China Power Grid. As demonstrated in B.6, the grid for baseline emissions
calculation is the East China Power Grid, whose geographical/physical boundaries can be clearly
identified and the information pertaining to the East China Power Grid and estimated baseline
emissions is publicly available3.
(cid:151) Condition 3: Nature gas is sufficiently available in the region or country, e.g. future nature gas based
power capacity additions, comparable in size to the project activity, are not constrained by the use of
nature gas in the project activity.
Natural gas is sufficiently available in Zhejiang Province. According to the Natural Gas Pipeline
Network Planning of Zhejiang Province (Gui-497, September of 2005), the natural gas supply of
Zhejiang Province comes from three sources: natural gas transferred from west, East China Sea gas
field and imported LNG. The natural gas supply is as follows:
Table B1 Natural Gas Supply in Zhejiang Province (unit: 108Nm3/a)

Context: 1.18 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Leakage Management
Two areas were included in the Leakage Management Area, as they are the nearest communities
to the Project Area. Further information about boundaries of the leakage management area is
located at section 3.3, Project Boundaries, of the present VCS PD.
• Pau-Brasil Settlement
• Casa de Tábua Settlement
More information on the relationship between the LMA and the Project, as well as the prospects
for socio-environmental activities will be further discussed on the Social Carbon Report, which
will be performed along with the 1st monitoring period.
The main objective of the project is to avoid unplanned deforestation. This goal will be achieved
through the expansion of monitoring of the area, along with the inclusion of the local community
in the project activities, with environmental education and alternative sources of income to
minimize risks of invasion and deforestation within the project area and the reference region.
As aforementioned throughout this project description document, the present REDD Project plans
to implement a program regarding the extraction of NTFPs as a way of providing an alternative
income source for the local communities that surround the project area.
Brazilian law such as Decree No. 6,040 ensures the rights of traditional people and communities
of attaining sustainable development, and by this, activities such as collection of forest products
are permitted as long as they do not cause any damage to the area in question35. Hereupon, the
34 Commitments available in Brazil’s iNDC, from 2016, and reinforced in its update in 2020/2021. Available at
<https://www4.unfccc.int/sites/NDCStaging/Pages/Party.aspx?party=BRA>
35 Further detailed information about legal guarantees is discussed on sections 1.14 and 2.5 of this document.
36

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
project proponents neither can (by law) or want to prohibit the local communities from collecting
NTFP in the project area.
Moreover, the project activities will enable the creation of jobs to monitor the area, prioritizing
the hiring of local residents for monitoring of the area, with professional training. Income from
the sale of credits will make it possible to invest in the educational and professional training of
children and adults in the community.
Beyond the project’s ecological and carbon benefits, the implementation of REDD and
SOCIALCARBON mechanisms promotes benefit sharing of carbon credits revenues.
The SOCIALCARBON methodology will serve as a plan and guideline for carrying out activities and
achieving goals, in addition to assessing progress in each monitoring period. In this way, the
owners are committed and add value to the carbon project with each action taken, encouraging
long-term sustainable development and driving continuous improvement in the local community
through prospects (at least one per Resource, totaling 6 improvement actions), on which the
project proponent undertakes to implement them until the next monitoring period.
To guarantee the progression of the socioenvironmental scenario in the region, the
SOCIALCARBON Standard requires that at least 50% of the actions suggested on the previous
Point assessed are implemented, under the risk of losing the Standard. The monitoring period
for SOCIALCARBON should be the same as the monitoring period for the Carbon Accounting
Standard.
Commercially Sensitive Information
No commercially sensitive information has been excluded from the public version of the project
description.
Further Information
No further information to disclose.
2 SAFEGUARDS
2.1 No Net Harm
The project is designed to not result in any negative impacts. On the other hand, it is expected
that the forest conservation project will result in several positive impacts for the environment,
biodiversity, and improvements on the socioeconomic conditions of local communities arising
from carbon revenues.
37

Context: 1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
According to the sectoral scopes under the VCS Program6, the Madre de Dios Amazon REDD
Project falls under the sectoral scope 14 Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use and according
to the VCS AFOLU Requirements7 it falls under the definition of a Reduced Emissions from
Deforestation and Degradation Project (REDD). Taking into account the definitions provided in
the VCS AFOLU Requirements, the Madre de Dios Amazon REDD Project can also be broadly
categorized as an Avoiding Unplanned Deforestation and Degradation (AUDD) Project (reduce
net GHG emissions by stopping deforestation and/or degradation of degraded to mature forests
that would have occurred in any forest configuration, can occur as a result of socio-economic
forces that promote alternative uses of forest land and the inability of institutions to control these
activities). In addition to this, the project occurs in a frontier deforestation, regarding the definition
included in the VCS AFOLU Requirements which states that the frontier deforestation and/or
degradation pattern can result from the expansion of roads and other infrastructure into forest
lands; roads and other infrastructure can improve forest access and lead to increased
encroachment by human populations, such as subsistence farming and fuelwood gathering on
previously inaccessible forest lands.
In addition to this and as required by the REDD-MF Module8 of the applied REDD Methodology
Modules, the following decision tree was used to identify the type of VCS-eligible REDD project
activity:
When asked if the forest land is expected to be converted to non-forest land in the baseline case,
the answer is YES, and when asked if the land is legally authorized and documented to be

{'project_name': 'Fangzheng-1 Water Management with Rice Cultivation', 'project_summary': 'The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittently flooded conditions during rice cultivation is conducted in the west of Fangzheng County, Harbin City, Heilongjiang Province, China, with a total acreage of 17,612 ha of single-cropping rice. Without the project, there would be no ditches, pumps, valves, and reservoirs to conduct the intermittently flooded method, the traditional continuously flooded method would be continued. The original scenario in which rice was cultivated by the continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Due to the anaerobic decomposition of organic matter in the paddy soil under flooded conditions, a large amount of methane can be released, so the intermittently flooded method is more conducive to saving water, improving rice yield and reducing methane emissions than the continuously flooded method.', 'project_state_province': 'Heilongjiang Province', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 45.83, 'project_longitude': 128.92}

Question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?

Context: 1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
According to the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) criteria, which is an approved GHG
program as per the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS), the project is in Sectoral Scope 1 – ‘Energy
Industries (renewable sources)’ and Sector 13 – ‘Waste handling and disposal’.
Hence as per the CDM guidelines, as per Appendix B of ‘Simplified modalities for small-scale
CDM project activities), the project activity falls into the following types:
1. Type I (renewable energy projects): Category C (thermal energy for the user)
2. Type III (other project activities): Category J (agriculture).
The project activity is a stand-alone activity and is not grouped with any other project.

The first group of instances will be located in the La Libertad department, Sanchez Carrión province, Chugay
district, including a total of 166.74 ha, belonging to 30 producers. From this area, the first 90.02 ha will be
forested in the first year of the project.
Each instance of project activity has been identified and a polygon defined using a GPS. The geographical
coordinates of the boundaries of each of the units includes a georeferencing process including UTM
coordinates with WGS 1984 S horizontal projection. This information is stored in a database data processed
and defined in ARCGIS Desktop4. Subsequently Digital KML files are generated, indicating the geographic
location and size of each project instance.

{'project_name': 'Reforestation of pasture lands on the Peruvian Northern Andes – “Forestry PRODICOM” Grouped Project', 'project_summary': 'The Reforestation of Pasture Lands on the Peruvian Northern Andes – “Forestry PRODICOM” Grouped Project proposed by SOCODEVI in association with Ecotierra and ADEFOR is an ARR carbon sequestration grouped project based on the development of cooperative enterprises composed by small local producers for the installation of 5,000 ha of new forest plantation in high altitude Andean pastures. >>
E.1. Brief description how comments by local stakeholders have been invited and compiled:
>>
The stakeholders identified for the project were the occupants of the villages around and the local
communities, NGOs, governmental agencies, BVUPL employees and contractors. Local population is
considered to be a major stakeholder with respect to the project activity.
The meeting started with the welcome address by the representative of BVUPL. He further explained
about the wind project taken up by the company. Representative of BVUPL further explained the purpose
of the meeting and detailed each questions in the questionnaire. He then explained about the advantages
of the wind energy generation with respect to it being a renewable source of power in the region.
The villagers wished to know the impact of WTGs on the environment in the region. Further to the
discussion, the representative of Suzlon Energy Limited explained that wind power generation is an eco-
friendly technology which will have no harmful effect on the environment. Finally the comments were
received from the stakeholder, which has been briefed in section E-2.

>>
According to the feedback received from the stakeholders which included farmers, laborers etc., due to
the erection of wind farms, the socio-economic situation in the area and the village people’s living
standard has been improved.
It was emphasized by the stakeholders that the project has not only provided employment but also
significantly contributed to the infrastructure development likes puccha roads.
The stakeholders also expressed satisfaction that the project would help alleviating the power deficit
currently being faced by the region.
E.3. Report on how due account was taken of any comments received:
>>
All comments were positive. No negative comments were received from stakeholders.

{'project_name': 'Shaanxi Foping Improved Forest Management Project', 'project_summary': 'The Shaanxi Foping Improved Forest Management Project (hereafter referred to as “the project”) is located in Foping County, Hanzhong City, Shaanxi Province, P.R.China. It is implemented by China Carbon Sinks Holdings Limited (PP) to protect the once logging forest. 
The proposed project is implemented in Chenjiaba Town, Daheba Town, Yueba Town, Yuanjiazhuang Town, Xichahe Town. The project has 7,011ha commercial forest, whose ages ranging from sapling, middle age to mature forest. Prior to the implementation of the project, Forests in the project area were harvested following the guidelines in Timber Harvest Plan approved by the local forestry bureau. 2 PROJECT DETAILS
2.1 Project Goals, Design and Long-Term Viability
2.1.1 SummaryDescriptionof the Project(VCS, 3.2,3.6, 3.10, 3.11,3.13, 3.14;CCB, G1.2)
Aksai Sustainable Grassland Management Project (hereafter as “the project”) is located in
Aksai Kazakh Autonomous County, Jiuquan City, Gansu Province of China. Aksai Kazakh
Autonomous County is located in the west of Gansu Province14. The objective of the
project is to restore the degraded grassland ecosystem through the sustainable grassland
management practices, such as improving the rotation of grazing animals between
grassland areas (called as rotational grazing), limiting the grazing duration on degraded
pastures (called as rest grazing), and replanting with perennial grasses (called as
reseeding grass), and using other appropriate management practices (like rodent and pest
control and grassland fire prevention), thereby increasing the accumulation of soil organic
carbon and realizing GHG removals.Participatory Rural Appraisal (PRA) report of the
project, before the implementation of the project, 168,000.83 ha of grassland within the
project area were moderately degraded due to overgrazing for the past decades,
24,394.50 ha of grassland within the project area were severely degraded due to
overgrazing for the past decades.
Besides these main restoration measures, the project also alleviates soil desertification and
restores grassland vegetation to improve soil carbon storage and local biodiversity through
other grassland management measures, such as daily management measures like rodent
and pest control and grassland fire prevention to ensure the long-term sustainable
managementofthe projectarea.
The project is estimated to generate GHG emission reductions and removals of 17,483,157
tCO e in 40 years, with an annual average of GHG emission reductions and removals 2
437,079 tCO e. 2
Climate: Restore the degraded grassland ecosystem, increase grassland coverage,
increasegrasslandcarbon sink function andreduceGHG emissions.
Community: Improve the livelihood of local herders/villagers, provide permanent and
temporary job opportunities for them, and increase their income. Provide technical skills and
training in sustainable grassland management, increase interaction within the community
andimprovethe well-being oflocalcommunities.
Biodiversity: Providemore suitable habitatsfor wild animals andincreaselocalbiodiversity.
The project area is located in Aksai Kazakh Autonomous County of Jiuquan city of Gansu
province of China. The geographical coordinates of the project area are east longitude
94°17′03"~96°00′10" and north latitude 38°35′14"~39°24′59",is not located within a
jurisdictioncovered by ajurisdictionalREDD+ program.

emissions and emission reductions and/or removals from project or program activities in the
agriculture, forestry, and other land use/land use change sectors. The project area shall not
be cleared of native ecosystems within the 10-year period prior to the project start date. The
category of improved Cropland Management (ICM),Grassland Management (IGM) and
Cropland and Grassland Land-use Conversions (CGLC) includes practices that reduce net
GHG emissions on croplands and grasslands by increasing carbon stock in soils and woody
biomassand/or decreasing CO ,N Oand/or CH emissionsfromsoils. 2 2 4
The project restores degraded grassland by planting grass and sustainable management of
grazing activities, thus increasing soil carbon stocks. So, the projectis developed under VCS
sectoral scope 14 “Agriculture, Forest and Other Land Use (AFOLU)” with a AFOLU project
category of Agricultural Land Management (ALM) and belongs to the ALM activities of
Improved Grassland Management (IGM) that demonstrably reduce net GHG emissions of
grassland ecosystems by increasing soil carbon stocks, reducing N O emissions and/or 2
reducing CH emissions.Theprojectisnotagrouped project. 4
Therefore,the Projectmeets theAFOLU-specificeligibility requirements.

2.2 Applicability of Methodology
The ACM0002 methodology is applicable to grid-connected renewable energy power generation
project activities that (paragraph 3):
(a) Install a Greenfield power plant;
(b) Involve a capacity addition to (an) existing plant(s);
(c) Involve a retrofit of (an) existing operating plants/units;
(d) Involve a rehabilitation of (an) existing plant(s)/unit(s); or
(e) Involve a replacement of (an) existing plant(s)/unit(s).
The proposed project activity envisages the construction and operation of the wind farm to
produce electricity at the site where no renewable power plant has been previously operated and
therefore the project falls under item (a)28. This project is connected to the grid of the Republic of
South Africa.29
The project meets all necessary applicability conditions of the ACM0002 to apply (see Table 2-1).

that the proposed project is not economically or financially feasible, without the revenue from the
sale of carbon credits.
TOOL24 is applicable as per paragraph 58 of TOOL01 since the project proponents apply
Common practise analysis in the demonstration of the additionality.
Tool (b) is not used as indicated in reference 2 to paragraph 9 of ACM0002.
Tool (c) is not used since project emissions for the project is zero as described in Section 3.2.2
below.
Tool (d) is applicable as per paragraph 68 of ACM0002 and paragraph 6(a) of the tool.
Tool (e) is not used since ASB0040-2018: Standardized baseline “Grid emission factor for
Southern African Power Pool” (Version 01.0) is used to determine the value of the emission factor

Context: 1.13 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Eligibility Criteria
Kiran HEPP is not a grouped project.
Leakage Management
As suggested in AMS-I.D/Version 17, the leakage emissions are not calculated and assumed to
be “0”. Please refer to item 22 in the methodology.
Commercially Sensitive Information
There is no information that needs to be excluded from the public version of the VCS PD which
will be displayed on the VCS Project Database.
Further Information
The project is a renewable energy project for power generation that enables the substitution for
fossil fuel based electricity. The contribution of the project activity towards sustainable
development in Turkey is regarded as follows:
 The project is not located in an area that is (a) legally protected, (b) officially proposed for
protection, (c) identified by authoritative sources for high conservation value, or (d)
recognized as protected by traditional local communities as confirmed in the Kiran HEPP
Project Description File, page 40.
 The same report highlights that the ecosystems surrounding the project site are not
endemic or endangered. The amount of minimum water to sustain the fauna, flora and
the agriculture in the basin is estimated and monitored by the State Water Works (DSI)
 The project owner guarantees to comply with this ‘minimum water rule”. Also the
company has constructed a fish pass at the regulator area of the plant to allow fish
migration to the upstream water.
 The Project will comply with the 4857 numbered Labor Law and its regulations. The
workers have been trained in line with the Health and Safety Regulations. There have
been on the job vocational training for those who does not have specific construction
experience. All the workers were benefit from trainings on construction health and safety.

not apply to the project. Other community plots do not fall under either of the categories

Context: 1.9 Project Crediting Period
In the registered VCS PD, the crediting period is described as from 01-Jan-2013 to 05-Sep-
2013. The project is registered under VCS Standard Version 3.4 and completed validation
before 19-Mar-2020. Thus, it remains eligible to apply the crediting period requirements under
VCS Standard Version 3, which shall be a maximum of ten years and may be renewed at most
twice. Hence, the first renewable crediting period of the project has been updated from 01-Jan-
2013to31-Dec-2022, rather thanfrom 01-Jan-2013to05-Sep-2013.
The project is also a registered CDM project (Ref.8237) with a 7*3 renewable project crediting
period, the VCS issuance is not eligible for beyond the end of those 21 years. Furthermore,
given that the VCS crediting period started on 01-Jan-2013 and the lifetime of the project is
about 20 years. The total VCS crediting period was determined from 01-Jan-2013 to 31-Dec-
2032, of which the first VCS crediting period is from 01-Jan-2013 to 31-Dec-2022 and the
second VCScreditingperiod isfrom01-Jan-2023to31-Dec-2032(10years).

2.2 Applicability of Methodology
The proposed activity is utilization of biomass (rice husk) for steam generation required for various
processes at the processing unit. Emission reductions due to the project activity are considered
equivalent to the emissions that would have occurred from combustion of fossil fuel in the baseline
scenario. Additionally, this is a small-scale project activity as the total annual thermal output is (9.17
MWthermal) less than 45 MWthermal (pls. refer worksheet “Thermal Output” for details). Hence, it
qualifies for the category C.

project activity vis-à-vis applicability conditions in the AMS-I.C version 19 is described in the following
table. This methodology comprises renewable energy technologies that supply users with thermal energy
that displaces fossil fuels under the following conditions

the project equipment. For boilers, condensate return (if any) must be incorporated into enthalpy of the feed.
11 A co-fired system uses both fossil and renewable fuels, for example the simultaneous combustion of both biomass
residues and fossil fuels in a single boiler. Fossil fuel may be used during a period of time when the biomass is not available and
due justifications are provided.

PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM-SSC-PDD) - Version 03
CDM – Executive Board
Technical Specifications:
The power generation scheme proposed envisages a single boiler with all its auxiliary systems
and an extraction cum condensing turbo-generator with all its auxiliary systems, HV and EHV
systems for the export of the power to the grid and the remaining balance of plant items to
complete the power plant.
The scheme envisages a 45 TPH capacity steam generator with the outlet steam parameters of 66
ata and 490 °C, with the feed water inlet temperature of 116.3 °C. The turbo-generator is Impulse
type, single extraction cum condensing turbine with water-cooled condensation system of 10
MW capacity. The plant is designed with all other balance of plant systems like the fuel handling
system, ash handling system, raw water system, cooling water system, de-mineralized water
system, compressed air system, HV and EHV systems etc. for its successful operation. The
scheme is configured to optimize the power generation, with one stage of feed water heating. The
extraction of steam and its usage in the deaerator for the feed water heating improves the
efficiency of the plant.
The generating voltage at the generator terminals is considered as 11 KV, which will be stepped
up to 33 KV state electricity grid level. The power produced will be evacuated to the grid of 33
kV sub-station at Shindola town situated at about 2 km from the proposed project location.
The project activity uses state of the art technology having modern safety features and pollution
control systems to ensure environmentally safe and sound operation.

Question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?

Context: 1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The Sectoral scope of this project corresponds to VCS Sectoral scope 14 (Agriculture, Forestry and
Other Land Use) and is categorized under VCS AFOLU category Reduced Emissions from
Deforestation and Degradation (REDD) as it seeks to reduce deforestation and degradation and to
enhancecarbon.
According to VCS Standard v4.2, the actions that reduce net GHG emissions by stopping
deforestation and/or forest degradation are considered eligible REDD activities. The activities
that directly influence degradation and deforestation, such as animal grazing, unsustainable
fuelwood extraction, unsustainable timber removal, or other such activities, need to be tackled
in order to reduce the emission of GHG. These unplanned activities leading to forest
degradation (AUDD) can be avoided through specific interventions that directly address the
respective drivers of degradation, for example, forest patrolling and fencing to control
unsustainable fuelwood and NTFP extraction, capacity-building programs to generate
alternative livelihood options and to control forest fire, incorporating rotational grazing,
providing van panchayat members with chaff-cutter, improved fodder plants to address
overgrazing, improved forest management practices and building trenches, chal-khal etc.
structurestoenrichsoilmoisture.
The project applies approved VCS methodology VM0037 “Methodology for Implementation of
REDD+ Activities in Landscapes Affected by Mosaic Deforestation and Degradation”. The project is
agrouped project.
1.3 ProjectEligibility
The project is eligible under the scope of the VCS Program as the project includes AFOLU activities
(project category REDD) which is supported by a methodology approved under the VCS Program. As
requiredinVCSstandard4.1,thisprojectmeetsthefollowingrequirements-
- Theproject meetsall applicablerules andrequirements setoutundertheVCSprogram.
- Theproject and the implementation of project activitiesdo not violateanyapplicable law as
mentioned insection1.14.
- This is an eligible AFOLU project category under VCS Program: Reducing Emissions from
DeforestationandDegradation(REDD)
- Implementationpartners areidentified intheprojectactivity;
- Thisprojectisnotlocated withinajurisdictioncovered byanyotherjurisdictional REDD+
program
- Thisprojectdoes notdrainnativeecosystemsordegradehydrological functions
- NoneoftheREDDactivitiesproduceanyozonedepleting substances.
- Theprojectisbeing developed withtheapprovedVCSmethodology VM0037“Methodologyfor
ImplementationofREDD+ ActivitiesinLandscapesAffectedbyMosaic Deforestationand
Degradation”.

{'project_name': 'JinNa Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation', 'project_summary': 'The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation is conducted in Zhijin County and Nayong County, Guizhou Province, where located in southwestern China with a total acreage of 18,958 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of this project, which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the backward continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emissions decrease than the continuously flooded.
The implementation activities of the project include cement ditch construction, reservoir construction and necessary training for farmers to help them conduct the intermittent flooded water regime during rice cultivation, which replaces the traditional flooded method. Controllable irrigation and drainage according to the needs of rice growth can not only save water resources, but also reduce methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions (flooded state). In this case, the CH4 emission can be declined by an average of 48% . Hence, with the proposed project activity, an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 3.20 tCO2e/ha for rice is expected.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 415,422 tCO2e in the first seven-year period, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 59,346 tCO2e.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes.
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers.
- Provide more job opportunities, especially female workers
- Use a proportion of benefits to improve the local children’s education', 'project_state_province': 'Guizhou Province', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 26.38, 'project_longitude': 105.37}

1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The proposed VCS ALM (Agricultural Land Management) project activity aims at developing a
carbon sequestration project as part of Integrated Watershed Development Programme (IWDP)
implemented by Godrej Properties Ltd. (GPL), the Project Proponent (PP) in collaboration with
the National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (NABARD), the active promoter of
participatory Watershed Development Programmes in the Government, Semi-government and
NGO sectors. The project integrates watershed development and the adoption of Sustainable
Agriculture Land Management (SALM) practices by Smallholder farmers within the proposed
watersheds. The villages which are selected for the Watershed Development Project under the
Watershed Development Fund (WDF) are Bavi, Jamb and Zapewadi in the BEED District of
Taluka. Shirur (K) of Maharashtra. The selected villages of Beed District, fall under the major
Drought Prone Areas (DAPs) of the Marathwada region and comes in the VIIth Agro-climatic zone
of the State such as Assured Rainfall Zone, where scarcity of ground water is acute. Through the
Watershed Management programme & sustainable farming under SALM, the PP aims at multiple
environmental assets for the smallholder farmers in the watershed area such as Sustainable
Water Management, Improved Carbon Sequestration (Soil & Tree Carbon Sequestration) and
Livelihoods.
The proposed project integrates sustainable agricultural land management practices aiming at
soil carbon enhancement, since agriculture is the main source of income for the farmers involved
in the project. Hence the overall goal of the project is to improve the livelihoods of small and
marginalized farmers in the project area by restoring their degraded agricultural lands through the
water & soil carbon conservation techniques and adopting SALM practices for the sustainable
farming. The PP focuses on the benefits of improved living conditions of the farmers and
increased yields arising from improved cultivation techniques by demonstrating synergies
between climate-change adaptation and mitigation strategies in agriculture.
The project activity has a three year roll out which begins in 28/07/2017 and ends in 27/07/2020.
The implementing SALM practices for the 3-year roll out period includes Nutrient Management
(Green manure, Cover crops, Composting Etc), Soil & Water conservation techniques
[Continuous Contour Trench (CCT), Water Absorption Trench (WAT), Pits, Stone Gully Plug
(SGP), Earthen Gully Plug (EGP) etc.], Agronomic practices and Agro forestry. About 50%-80%
of the land area adopted by SALM activities during the first 2 years and the entire area will be
covered for the implementation during the third year. The project is undertaken by the small scale
farmers in the entire project area i.e 3274.65 Ha across in three watersheds.The proposed
project activity comes under the eligible AFOLU Project category of Agricultural Land
Management (ALM) and under the sub category of eligible ALM activities - Improved Crop land
Management (ICM). The applicability of ALM Project activity in this project encompasses
v3.3 3

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
activities that increase soil & tree carbon sequestration through improved water management
and/ reduce GHG emission by establishing, increasing or restoring vegetative cover through
SALM Practices. The implementation of the proposed project activity under the Verified Carbon
Standard (VCS) scheme promotes the sustainable development in the region, brings benefits to
the local communities and to the whole carbon offset mitigation.
The project foresees achievement of GHG mitigation through soil & tree carbon sequestration.
Additionally, the project seeks to generate socio-economic benefits including poverty alleviation
and potential long term income stream to the participating farmers. In this perspective land
management practices under watershed management can reduce greenhouse gas emissions
and prevent climate change by enhancing carbon storage in soils; conserving existing soil
carbon; and decreasing GHGs emissions. This also improves their food security, which is now
more important than ever given the vulnerability to climate change.
The estimate of annual average GHG reductions and removals through adoption of SALM
practices in the agricultural landscape is 33764 tCO e and total reductions estimations are 2
675272 tCO e. The Project activities are carried out and monitored according to approved VCS 2 methodology VM0017: Adoption of Sustainable Agricultural Land Management1 for a crediting
period of 20 years renewable.

Context: 1.18 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Leakage Management
No leakage is expected to occur in the project area due to planned project activities and is therefore
considered to be zero as it is stated in section 4.3 of this document.
34

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
The project will be established mainly on family-owned plots. Farmers in the project area cultivate on
their own land, so there will be no displacement that could cause leakage. Displacement of pre-project
agricultural activities is not foreseen and, if it occurs, it will be to land with SOC and biomass stocks
equal to or lower than the original agricultural land. Therefore, leakage is considered to be zero.
Commercially Sensitive Information
No commercially sensitive information has been excluded from the public version of the project
description.
Further Information
Not Applicable as there is no additional relevant information, since everything is mentioned in this PDD
and other relevant documents.
2 SAFEGUARDS
2.1 No Net Harm
Environmental Impact: the project has a demonstrably positive impact on the environment,
underpinned by rigorous criteria for selecting eligible plots. The project has implemented a robust
operational framework with comprehensive monitoring and follow-up mechanisms to mitigate any
adverse effects on the territory.
The project's environmental benefits are substantial and closely intertwined with the socio-economic
well-being of the local communities. Through the strategic implementation of agroforestry systems, crop
rotation, intercropping techniques, and the incorporation of plant cover, the project has achieved a
range of highly favourable outcomes. These measures serve as effective safeguards against soil
erosion, enriching the agro-biodiversity of the land, and providing coffee growers with diversified income
sources.
Notably, these environmentally friendly practices not only safeguard natural resources but also yield
tangible socio-economic advantages for the communities involved. By embracing sustainable
agricultural techniques, our project not only minimises negative impacts but actively promotes positive
outcomes. This holistic approach harmoniously balances environmental conservation with the
economic well-being of local communities, ensuring the enduring impact of our efforts and fostering a
sustainable future.
Our commitment to preserving natural areas is steadfast, and our criteria for plot selection are
designed to avoid deforestation. We understand the critical importance of safeguarding natural
habitats and have established stringent guidelines to ensure that our project never encroaches on
these valuable ecosystems.
35

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
Furthermore, our operational framework is meticulously designed to monitor and evaluate the project's
impact continuously. We proactively address any potential negative consequences, swiftly adapting our
strategies to mitigate them.
Social Impact: the project adheres to the fundamental principle of Free, Prior and Informed Consent
(FPIC), recognizing it as an essential collective human right belonging to Indigenous Peoples and Local
Communities (IP/LC). This right empowers these communities to grant or withhold their consent prior to
the initiation of any project that could impact their rights, lands, resources, territories, livelihoods, and
food security.
In the context of potential social impacts, it is worth noting that Oaxaca boasts a diverse and culturally
rich environment, home to approximately 19 distinct ethnic groups coexisting harmoniously. These
groups and communities have established internal governance mechanisms that enable active
participation in decision-making processes, fostering representation, diversity, and a deep-rooted
connection to their ancestral territories.
The project's implementation is entrusted to CEPCO, a reputable social organisation with a remarkable
track record spanning over three decades, primarily dedicated to collaborating with coffee growers in
the region. CEPCO has consistently demonstrated a genuine commitment to the welfare of the territory
and its residents, endowing it with the legitimacy required to promote sustainable development
initiatives.
CEPCO operates through a network of 45 cooperatives, each governed by its own committee
responsible for representing and coordinating its members. Across the 7 distinct regions organised by
CEPCO, representatives are democratically elected to serve on the State Council. This Council convenes
on a monthly basis and maintains a continuous presence at CEPCO's central offices during their two-
year mandate, diligently overseeing the organisation's activities.
Every two years, a comprehensive assembly convenes, bringing together 400 to 500 farmers hailing
from various corners of the state. It is within this assembly that the project underwent a thorough
process of socialisation, consultation, and agreement, involving all the hierarchical structures within
the CEPCO governance framework. Ultimately, the project was presented to and received approval from
the general assembly, affirming its alignment with the principles of FPIC (Free, Prior and Informed
Consent), and its commitment to respecting the rights and values of the Indigenous Peoples and Local
Communities of Oaxaca.

Context: E.2. Summary of the comments received:
>>
The stake holders meetings were conducted at the respective project sites and were attended by the office
bearers and residents of the nearby villages and those employed in the project activity. The local villagers
and the office bearers expressed their happiness with the setting up of the power project in their village as
it had resulted in generation of direct and indirect employment opportunities both for literate and illiterate
people. They also hoped that with the setting up of wind power plant, the quality of power supply would
also improve and would also help in agricultural activities. They also informed that the land prices in the
village had appreciated due to the setting up of the power project in the village. The employees hired for
the project activity from the local area stated that the project activity has provided them with a means of
livelihood in their own village and will help them in getting equipped with technical skills. They stated
that such skills would help them in their career development.
